reviewText: Although the show has a science fiction premise, the story is advanced through character development. The interesting thing is that most of the characters are played by Tatiana Mazlany.The main character, Sarah Manning, is a grafter and petty criminal who lives with her gay foster brother, Felix. Sarah is the mother of a young child, Kira, who is living with Sarah's foster mother because Sarah has been unable to care for the child.One day, Sarah is standing near a train line when she sees a woman who strongly resembles Sarah. The woman is talking excitedly on a phone, but then hangs up and jumps in front of the train. Sarah takes advantage of the opportunity to steal her handbag. She finds that the dead woman is a dead ringer for herself, so eventually, Sarah assumes her identity as a policewoman named Beth Childs. You can see how the complexity ensues.It doesn't take long for Sarah to learn that she is one of numerous clones, all of whom have different personalities and interests and all of whom are played by Ms. Mazlany. Of course, the show includes the obligatory evil corporation which is unrestrained by any laws, and the obligatory powerful religious cult, also heedless of law. So Sarah s off to learn about and fight them all, as well as protect her daughter, her foster brother, and the other clones.This is an excellent fast paced action series.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: OB overloads the mystery and mayhem, but when it settles down to story building rather than just suspense building it is a rich, addicting experience.  A strange family is coming together and the viewer is drawn into their survival.  It is often laugh out loud funny.  Helena and Sarah on a roadtrip.  Lookout rural Canada.

reviewText: I am so far from a TV addict, I watch very little, but I cannot look away from this show. Tatiana Maslany is simply amazing; she is an incredibly talented and gifted actor. She makes the show, but the writing -- especially the dialog, the production -- for instance the music and sets -- and the roller coaster plot make this one of the best  TV shows out there. I would put it in the same league as X-Files, which in my mind is an all-time high point in television. Another attractive feature here is the complexity of characters as they transition from good to evil and back again. Characters who enter as repugnant are often rehabilitated as their story unfolds and the writing masterfully keeps the audience on-board through these transitions. This show is a mix of ordinary suspense joined with the real looming complications introduced by synthetic biology all navigated by an ingenious but not invulnerable heroine. Does it get much better than that?
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Sarah Manning and her 'sisters', Cosima and Alison, find their loyalties divided when Sarah's daughter Kira disappears. Sarah believes that the Dyad Institute, which Cosima works for, is responsible, whilst it appears that a group of fanatics known as the Proletheans may also be trying to hurt Sarah and her newfound family. Secrets from thirty years ago re-emerge as all the factions involved in this struggle try to find the secret to flawless genetic engineering, no matter the cost.Orphan Black's first season was the undoubted SF TV highlight of 2013, with Tatiana Maslany turning in a powerhouse performance as multiple versions of the same character. Some clever writing and strong supporting turns, not to mention pitch-perfect pacing, made the show even better. This second season has a lot to live up to.For the most part, it works. The pacing remains strong and the writers do an excellent job of answering past mysteries whilst making new revelations and setting up fresh puzzles. They also resist the urge to play "Clone of the Week", instead restricting themselves to exploring the character of Rachel (introduced at the end of Season 1) and briefly touching on the lives of two other clones (one solely, but still heartbreakingly, through video diaries). Other characters like Dr. Leekie, Alison's troubled husband Donnie and the ever-more-formidable Mrs. S are fleshed out further and there's some strong newcomers in the form of Michael Huisman as Cal (impressing more than his recent, underwritten appearance on Game of Thrones, it has to be said), Michelle Forbes as Marion and Ari Millen as Mark Rollins. There's still a rich vein of humour, particularly in Alison and Felix's stories, as well as tenderness. The romance between Cosima and Delphine is particularly well-handled.Elsewhere, the show can't quite match the first season's near-effortless-seeming grace. Some characters get lost in the mix for long periods, with Art and Paul not getting very much to do. One character's return from the dead is highly unconvincing, although it does eventually lead to some of the best scenes in the series to date. The series also flirts with M. Night Shyamalanisms with the Village-esque scenes at the Prolethean farm going on for a bit too long. Also, the threat of Kira constantly being kidnapped gets old quickly and starts to get a bit too reminiscent of Hera in Battlestar Galactica. There's also a feeling that Vic gets parachuted into the show again when he doesn't really have much of a reason for being there beyond fan service, but given that his story is pretty funny we can forgive that.If its second season is a little bit more inconsistent than the first, Orphan Black (****) still remains the best SFF show on television thanks to its clever writing, dark humour (including the most wince-inducing death scene I've ever seen in anything) and its outrageously good performances, particularly from its leading lady. Roll on Season 3.
summary: Still the best SF show on television

Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Season Two is just about as jam packed as the first season with action and adventure. This is all to the good as the same actress still plays multiple roles as clones of one woman. She does a terrific job. My favorite clone remains the housewife out in the burbs, Alison, who can often be unexpectedly deadly. She is a riot and I love every minute she is on screen. Felix, the faithful gay friend, is back as well. I like him best when he is with Alison too. They are funny together. Perhaps the very best moments though are when Alison is forced into rehab, her husband Donny confronts her there and then Donny, in one of the funniest tv moments ever, accidentally kills one of her worst enemies by pounding a gun against his steering wheel in frustration.The other clones vary. Sarah has a very big role and she gets in the most fixes of any of them. However, her clone "sister" a Russian terminator is great at killing off anyone who gets in Sarah's way. Another great moment is when the Russian clone is dancing in a bar with a fellow and someone bothers her partner. Her partner is overwhelmed but she is not. She beats the crap out of guy bothering them! There are more clones as well but just tune in and watch Tatiana Maslany act her butt off playing all of them.This is a BBC production and Tatiana Maslany is from Toronto. One warning, you definitely need to see this in order. So watch season one first.
summary: Picks Up Right Where It Left Off
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: As of season two, this young woman has played no fewer than eight different incarnations of her character, and she has made each of them brilliant, exciting, mysterious and amusing. It's a good story, which could easily have been muddied with a lesser actress. When season two was released, I went back and binged on season one before moving forward, to be sure I kept straight the lines of this complex vision of science and reality crashing into one another head-on. It's good summer watching...beats the hell out of reruns. Give it a try, watch the first episode. If you're not interested in Sarah and Felix after that, you probably won't ever be interested...and a watch is only 44-52 minutes of your life.
summary: Watch this if only for Tatiana Maslany

reviewText: "Orphan Black" is one of those rare shows that keeps getting better and better as it goes on. The writing is amazing, the story lines are gripping, and the characters are all engaging (whether you like them or not). Tatiana Maslany portrays multiple clones, and each one is widely different. Sarah is the hero. Cosima is the brain. Alison is the often hysterical, high-strung soccer mom. Rachel is the opportunistic  corporate CEO. And Helena is the semi insane psychopath. I love them all. Season 2 ends soon (which saddens me). I cannot wait until Season 3.

Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: For those who are not in the loop yet, this is a fantastic show about clones who have just recently become self-aware, and are banding together to figure out what kind of perverse experiment they are being subjected to. Tatiana Maslany plays the clones, and the different personalities that she has created are fantastic.The show is a five-star+ show. This DVD I rate as 4 stars because none of the episodes have any commentary tracks. It is precisely this type of show where I would love to listen in to the creators and actors talking about an episode, and get an insider's "look" at the creative process. There are several excellent extras that explain how certain sequences are done, and how the show moves from script to finished product. My favorite extras explained how a fight was staged between Sarah and Rachel, early in the season, and how a dance party with Sarah, Cosima, Alison and Helena was staged and shot. Truly amazing movie magic at work here.
summary: 5+ Star Show Gets a 4 Star DVD
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Second Seasons are tough, especially trying to follow the stellar 10 episode run that introduced Orphan Black. Tatiana Maslany blew everyone away with a bravura display of MPD-acting, a feat that I doubt many actresses could have pulled off. Her portrayals of Sarah, Cosima, Helena, et al, were amazingly fleshed out, believable characters that were in some cases so profoundly different that you could forget they were being played by the same actress. As great as Maslany was in Season 1, however, she was not a one-man-band; the writing on the series has been excellent, managing the difficult task of keeping the action fresh and unpredictable. And although the very premise of Orphan Black is a favorite science fiction 'deus ex machina' device for lazy hacks (clones, a long lost evil twin, amnesia, time travel, psychic premonitions...), this has been a fairly realistic show. Cloning is a very real thing, and although the conspiracies and cover-ups are very obviously fictional, there's nothing that has occurred in Orphan Black that couldn't have happened in our world. The writers and directors realized this, and treated the series like the thriller it is, full of secrets and intrigue and betrayals. And then there was the supporting cast, made up largely of Canadians, like Maslany, who could easily be forgotten if they didn't do such amazing jobs themselves, creating unforgettable characters like Felix and Vic.Orphan Black survived it's Second Season crucible admirably, however. The writing and directing is just as sharp, taking the viewer deeper into the history of Project Leda, introducing new characters and groups with nefarious goals of their own. The Dyad Corporation sees some internal power struggles, and the various clones face dangers on all sides. That's about all you can say without throwing around spoilers, and this is the kind of show where spoilers are truly aggravating. Orphan Black continues to quietly insinuate itself into the Top Ten list for best drama on television.
summary: Quietly Insinuating Itself As A Top Ten Series
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: I can't say enough great things about this clone thriller adventure series. It's had me riveted and I keep buying the episodes even though it kills me to have to pay for them. Every dang episode has a cliffhanger and I think about each episode long after I have watched it. The cast and acting are spectacular, the unsung makeup artists rock the transformations, and there are characters that I love and love to hate. The plotline is never trite and I am seriously hooked on this series like I might freak out if it was ever canceled. Great writing of dialogue. My only complaint was the silly dancing scene, which I know took quite a bit of computer wizardry, but almost made the series jump the shark. Eh, hope they don't do that again. Stick to the story and remember the lesson well of Xena Warrior Princess and how the musical numbers made the series descend into an abyss that the fans could never get over. Other than that, carry on, Orphan Black. I love ya!

reviewText: Orphan Black is one of those rare shows that hit the ground running in its first season and quickly established itself as a smartly written, well-plotted mystery that executes a gimmick flawlessly. Tatiana was clearly overlooked in the awards for her ability to play multiples characters so convincingly that you often completely forget that all the primary players are the same person. Throw in the typical BBC style of delivering understated subtlety (in the midst of clones) and you have an intelligent, unique show that didn't paint itself into a corner and kept the audience guessing.Fast forward to season two and apart from the exceptional lead actress, it's like they fired all the original writers and decided to jump the shark during the season break. There has been an explosion of weak secondary characters introduced for no reason other than to create B plots - from the cliched nutty religious group to the horribly cliched evil genetics company run seemingly by a handful of people and headed by one kindly grandfatherly (but evil) guy, it's hard to engage seriously with any of these 2-dimensional setups.Season 2 has failed to create a central dramatic question and has instead opted to use poor dialog to create weak tension that only serves to get the audience to the next scene. The dialog has devolved into exposition where at any given time characters are explaining backstory to the audience, searching for something or trying to find someone that introduces the next step of the odyssey. And the problem with this is that it's lost the dramatic tension that made the audience care in the first place, and now characters are making illogical decisions and operating in a consequence-free vacuum.I delayed writing this review in the hopes that the episodes would get back on track but at this point it seems to be a lost season. I can only hope that if it gets renewed they have a serious rethink about how bring back the elements that made the first few episodes so engaging. Take away the extraordinary acting ability of Tatiana Maslany and it's pretty clear that this entire season has been treading water.
summary: A totally different show in season 2
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: ORPHAN BLACK was the new "water-cooler" show that caught most everyone by surprise when it began airing on BBC America last year, and suddenly the name that was everyone's lips was Tatiana Maslany, who had floundered in obscurity in small, thankless roles for the years of her career preceding it, but was now suddenly being hailed as one of the best new actresses currently working in any medium. A high-concept sci-fi drama/thriller by creators John Fawcett and Graeme Manson, ORPHAN BLACK primarily follows short con artist Sarah Manning, a beautiful and streetwise young British woman now living in Vancouver with her foster mother Mrs. S (Maria Doyle Kennedy), a feisty, hyper-protective Irishwoman who watches over Sarah's young daughter Kira (Skyler Wexler), and fellow Brit and bohemian foster brother Felix (Jordan Gavaris), who watches a lookalike kill herself right in front of her, and decides to take on her identity only to find that the woman who killed herself was a clone, and that Sarah has at least four other clones: Beth, the clone that Sarah assumed the identity of, was a police detective with dark secrets she kept from her partner, Art (Kevin Hanchard); Alison, a ferocious suburban soccer mom; Cosima, a science super geek, and Helena, a Ukrainian-raised half-crazed zealot who was taught to hunt her other clones by an extremist anti-science group calling themselves the Proletheans. Most of them have "monitors", or people assigned to watch them and regularly test them unbeknownst to the clones. Beth had Paul (Dylan Bruce), a war vet with dark secrets of his own. Alison has her oafish husband Donnie (Kristian Bruun). Cosima has Delphine (Evelyn Brochu), a fellow scientist who Cosima falls in love with. All of these monitors report to Dr. Aldous Leekie (Matt Frewer), the head of the Dyad Institute, who SEEMS to be running this experiment.Of course, like all great seralized high-concept dramas, nothing in the universe of ORPHAN BLACK is as it seems.In Season Two, everything goes up for grabs. A new clone is introduced in the personage of Rachel, a cold, calculating, and ruthless woman who is near the top of Dyad. Helena, thought dead after Sarah shot her, returns and is being held by a gentler version of the Proletheans. Cosima is sick with whatever auto-immune disease that we learn killed other clones, and was killing Katja (the second clone Sarah met, before being murdered right in front of her by Helena). Alison is increasingly paranoid about who her real monitor is. Sarah, on the run with Kira and Felix, meets up with Kira's former mark and baby daddy Cal (Michiel Huisman). Paul's allegiances switch from Sarah to Rachel. Delphine gets pushed and pulled between her love for Cosima and her loyalty to Dyad and Leekie. Felix has to help Alison out of several jams she gets herself into. Mrs. S seems to have one of the biggest and darkest secrets of all, though.And all of that doesn't even really begin to scratch the surface of this second season, which is perhaps even better than the first.Skip the clever story arcs, the terrific dialogue, the technical wizardry of having two (or more) clones in the same shot at the same time, the incredibly diverse characters and great representation of the LGBT community without making them into offensive caricatures. All of that is secondary to the master class in acting that Maslany puts on every episode. Giving each clone their own unique voice, posture, rhythm and movement is SO good and SO convincing that you literally forget that when you're watching the clones interact with each other that they're all the same actress. It also makes you wonder why the hell Maslany hasn't won an infinite amount of awards for her performance, especially after winning the Critic's Choice awards two years in a row.ORPHAN BLACK is a really good show, but with Maslany anchoring it so effortlessly, it transcends its genre and becomes some of the best television currently on.
summary: Tatiana Maslany gives the performance(s) of the year again as ORPHAN BLACK expands its world.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

Combining her performance with a truly excellent supporting cast makes it the total deal. I recommend it to anyone who loves a good action tail. reviewText: Super addictive, very entertaining! This is definitely a fun show. I had left it alone for the first season but on a whim gorged the first season. Had to buy the second season, couldn't stop watching. So many twists and turns, Maslany has got to be exhausted!

reviewText: I am so ready every week for the episodes. I cannot even decide who of them I like the best of the characters.  The story line is intense and riveting. Definitely worth giving a try. The best part of all of it is it is the fastest 40 minutes. You blink and the episode is over which is the sign of good writers!
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Orphan Black has many things going for it, original premise, a series of fine directors, a steady bunch of writers who haven't veered off their original course. The filming on location gives it a special visual sense. But, most of all it has Tatiana Mazlany. A 28 year old actress who has talent enough for 11 people. She is simply stunningly brilliant. The role calls for her to assume several identities, some all on screen at once. It must be a terribly strenuous undertaking. Honestly, she is so chameleon like, I actually forget it is the same actress. the make-up department is awesome at subtle differences in her characters, but it really all comes down to her talent. A small supporting cast does fine work. and  after, let's see, the 14 episodes I have seen, the writers are doing a great job of keeping me interested. So far there are two seasons of 10 shows each. I believe I read where a 3rd season has been put in the works. I was really just blown away in just the pilot episode.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Season 2 just started, but just want to say this is the best show on TV right now. Tatiana, is awesome, and really pulls it off. I was hooked from day one, and can't wait to watch the next episode. I love it.

reviewText: Word of Orphan Black is growing. The first season had a bunch of twists and the second season just gets more interesting.Tatiana has GOT to win an Emmy this year after being nominated last year. The whole cast is just amazing. One of the must see shows. I DVR the show but this episode got accidentally deleted so I bought it to keep up with the storyline. One of the best shows on TV.

Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: When I first started watching Orphan Black, I was immediately taken in by the talented Tatiana Maslany. But then I was amazed by the sheer volume of talent they must have on that set. The supporting actors, such as the brilliant and clever Jordan Gavaris and Dylan Bruce, deliver believable characters. The actors alone do not make the show, the creative team, the editors, and the cinematography team. The way they put everything together is just astonishing. My favorite character is Helena. I know what a lot people will say, "But she's out of her mind!" The Helena character is not only well-written but well-executed. You know from the get go what she is about, you know if you cross her she will most likely kill you, plus, she has no problem telling it like it is.Second season did not let me down but only pulled me in further. With the expanded story line of an already stunning story line, the characters so well-developed they were palpable. Season two has left me hungry for season 3.
summary: Easily one of the most thrilling shows on TV
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: The cast is incredible. When I was introduced to this show I had missed several episodes so I binge watched until I got through and then had to wait to the new season. Now I have to wait a week to see the next episode. I hate waiting!

Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: This show has '(well) made for cable in Toronto' written all over it production-wise, but the writing and acting are better then you might expect, especially for the lead - Canadian actress Tatiana Maslany - who has several top-shelf characters and portrays each one very thoughtfully.Its obvious in many scenes there is camera trickery to get her multiple characters in the same scene, but she does an amazing job of making that transparent in the interaction.Whenever there is a supernatural element I kind of roll my eyes about where everything is going (think Lost) - but I'm into the beginning of the second season and I have been pleasantly surprised with the quality of the plot.Jordan Gavaris is pitch-perfect as the lovable gay mess of a brother - by far my favorite character.Maria Doyle Kennedy is the touchstone seasoned veteran actress (think Ron White in Serendipity) who is always a joy to watch.In a delightfully surprise treat, Matt Frewer (know to us older folks as Max Headroom) - turns in the best straight acting performance I've seen. HIs character is more complex then the acting turns he's taken before and its enjoyable.(Possible Spoilers)There are a couple of artistic licenses you need to give the story. The first is that despite known circumstances, none of the characters seem at all concerned about their phones or homes being under surveillance, which would seem very likely.The second is that the transformation of the main character from a low-life grifter into an extremely functional and quick-thinking detective (both literally and figuratively) is pretty much instantaneous.This is hard to forget when her ex-boyfriend constantly reappears, and you think 'I don't care who she was supposed to be before, someone with this personality would never chose that guy to begin with'.Definitely try Orphan Black.
summary: A nice sleeper cable hit that's better then you might think
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Based on the orginal series this one should be a winner also!  A very slick British series with most of it taking place in the USor what is made to look like the US.  Interesting storyline and a great cast.

reviewText: Awesome show. You've never seen anything like this. Very unpredictable and addicting. Beware- you might  in to work because you stayed up too late watching it.

reviewText: Trust me, you will want to binge watch this.  You can't just watch one episode.  And when you are done, you'll want to re-watch it again. It's that good.  It's hard to believe that Tatiana is even better in season 2, than she was in season 1 (even though the plot gets kinda clunky at times).  Still, this is first rate television and despite the fact that this season is on my DVR, I am buying these disks so I'll have this show for a good long time.
summary: Tatiana Maslany is even better this season
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Tatiana M. is such a great actress to watch with all those different personalities! I love this show and hope there will be a Season 3. The only complaint I have is when they introduced "Tony" into the clone batch.  They did not work for me at all.  Especially the hair-do on Tony. They could have put Tatiana's hair in a wig that more resembled a guy. Dirty looking dreadlocks would have worked. Tony is totally unbelievable as a guy. The makeup artist failed on that one. I hope he doesn't come back.  Otherwise, this show is really a great watch! Helena is a trip!  I went from fearing her to loving her since she is so wacked out, poor thing. She can't help herself though. She is what she is. Watch this show. It is full of surprises, suspense and great acting. Felix is soooo adorable and is one of my favorites. My whole family is hooked on this show. Can't wait for episode 11!
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Found that season one was very absorbing.  Interesting concept and story lines.  Season two gets a little more complex and I find the characters a little less interesting.  Still looking forward to the continuing story line, though.

reviewText: Season 2 can be pretty much summed up as riding in the boot (trunk) of a car.  You think you know where you are going, then boom, you're off in another direction.  The acting has been top notch and Tatiana Maslany continues to shine in her ever widening roles. Again, no spoilers or plot hints.  You need to watch it unfold before your eyes.  I'm looking forward to the DVD's release in July.
summary: the mushrooming plot of Season 1, has become a wormhole of multiple tangents and misdirection..
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Why does Amazon allow people to review products that don't exist? Somehow not only do they allow such things, but they actually sent me an e-mail suggesting I review this pre-ordered, non-existent product. (FYI, it's now February 12, 2014. The show begins April 19, 2014 and who knows when this DVD set is coming out? I figured by pre-ordering I'll get a good price by ordering as soon as possible.)So, is this DVD set any good? Well, the first season was great but as I write it's the only season there is so far. So . . .No idea. But I'll give this product four stars. Perhaps it deserves five. After all, no joke, season one was a truly great show and I was just blown away by it. If you haven't seen it, well, a) go see it as soon as possible, and, b) why are you checking reviews for the second season of the show when you haven't checked out the first yet? GO SEE THE FIRST SEASON!! IT'S FANTASTIC!!!So, normally I'd give it five stars. --But I'll only give it four stars because . . . because it doesn't exist! I think that for a product to achieve five star perfection, well, it must be real, tangible and existent. Otherwise, well . . . it's about as good as that new novel that I haven't written yet.(But, hey, don't blame me. Amazon's computer specifically *requested* that I review this because it saw I pre-ordered it! I'm only doing as asked.))Anyway, I have seen the leaked writers' notes for the upcoming season.I loved the part where the clones all hosted SNL. The part where they all died was upsetting though. I cried for weeks.And, finally, if you haven't checked out season one, go do so. If you have, chances are you'll check out season two as well.
summary: Wow!! What a concept! Too bad it doesn't exist yet.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: I love everything about this series EXCEPT the fact that it paints Bible believers either as sanctimonious, hypocritical nutcases or terrorist sociopaths. The "religious" people in this series (i.e. Allison, Helena, and Helena's handlers) are being associated (albeit, loosely) with Christianity, even though they don't practice anything resembling the teachings of Christ. This can leave viewers who have never read the Gospels with an EXTREMELY skewed understanding of what it means to be a Christian.It's also dishonest and cowardly of the entertainment industry to keep associating Christianity with terrorism when everyone knows the overwhelming majority of terrorists in the world are Muslims. Let me clarify here that I'm NOT saying most Muslims are terrorists; I'm saying most terrorists are Muslims, and that's a FACT. The media and entertainment industry don't have the courage to associate Islam with terrorism, so they pick on Christianity, which is an easier target.And why is Christianity the easier target? Because Christians aren't retaliating with death threats, frivolous law suits, and violent rioting the way some Muslims do when Islam is insulted (e.g. riots around the world over Muhammad cartoons, death threats to Comedy Central for depicting Muhammad on South Park, the murder of the U.S. Ambassador in Benghazi, supposedly because of anti-Islamic movie trailers).Ironically, Christianity's PEACEFUL character is what makes it the primary target for bigoted, anti-religious attacks, even to the point of being associated with terrorism. Equally ironic, because of Islam's history of VIOLENT and EXTREME reactions to criticism, it has become the religion that no one wants to label as "violent" or "extremist"!Smh.
summary: Fantastic! Except for the clear anti-"Christian" implications
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Completely addicted to this show!! The acting is great and the editing is flawless. Cant wait for the next episode to become available.

reviewText: We started watching this and have binge watched until we caught up to the current episodes.  The initial episode was a bit reminiscent of Ringer (that show with Sarah Michelle Gellar where her twin "died" and SMG took over her life) but then it diverged into something like I've never seen before.  The whole clone concept is fascinating and it is truly amazing that one actress plays all of these roles.  Tatiana Maslany definitely deserves an award for this show.Definitely recommend for those looking for a show that is completely unique from most shows out there.  I didn't expect to like this show so much but it is captivating.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Love this show.  Tatiana Maslany is an amazing actor, and wonderfully fun to watch!  I enjoyed the 1st season, and also love the 2nd season.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Can't wait for each new episode. The twists and turns of this show keeps me guessing. Tatiana Maslany is an incredible actress and not hard to look at either.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Let me get this, up front. I'm an old guy, seen decades of TV, and it takes a bit to impress me.  Tatiana has raised the bar for every other actress out there.Sometimes the timing of events seems a bit off. People get somewhere quicker than possible. But with my other favorite show being about an old guy, running about the universe in a police box, I can forgive a little timing problem.No spoilers but. Sarah is showing much growth this season, the former con artist is growing into a mom, and friend to the others.Alison is a mess, we'll see how the season goes.Cosima, looks like the search for her cure, could open a huge rift at Dyad.Rachel, more and more the controlling, cold ........(fill in your own word).Now to the character that's growing on me. Helena.  Once you get past the over-the-top psychopathic, serial killer thing, she has her humorous side. Also when you get there, Helena provides two moments with Sarah "The Shower Scene" and then next episode "The Sniper Scene". You will know when you get there. These should make an Emmy a lock for Tatiana this year.Probably been mentioned before, but. Save this show for after the little ones are in bed. Really there's no full on nudity, due only to very careful editing, but you might find yourself having to explain things to small children, that you're not quite ready for.
summary: And I thought season 1, was as good as TV could get.

Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: UPDATE: OK, I've been re-watching Season 2.  I stand by my review below; except I think I was suffering from recency effect. My comment about fatigue among the writers mostly affects the episodes at the very end of the season, and even there, only pertains to a few of the plot elements.  Season 2 as a whole is a great continuation of Season 1. I'm shifting allegiances though, Kira is rapidly becoming my favorite character.  Not an easy choice, given Felix and all the clones, but there it is.MILD SPOILERS AHEAD: A step back in Season 2, but still a whole lot of fun.  There are some very good plot threads in Season 2, but there are too many overall, and the surplus story arcs end up diluting the good ones.  By the end of the season, it almost feels like the writers are exhausted, losing track, running out of ideas, and just wanted to get the season over with so they could take a break (a pencil from a fire extinguisher? Really?).  In spite of my quibbles, Season 2 still hit some of the highest points of the series. The shower scene in Rachel's apt. was just phenomenal (the best scene in the entire series, for me anyway), and Helena continued being a source of wonder ("I'm very good with children").  The CGI continues to amaze, Maslany is superb, the actors overall carry it as well as they can; and that's good enough for me.
summary: Good enough (and still better than most)
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: If you liked House of Cards you will love this one. Outstanding series with enough gut wrenching twists and turns that you will be willing TO PAY FOR SEASON 2. I am a cheap guy but I couldn't wait. A first for me.By the way, if you haven't seen House of Cards, DON'T MISS IT! Wow!

reviewText: Tatiana Maslany may be the most talented actress to come along in a generation or two. Handling all of the roles of all of the clones is a feat that we have never witnessed. She is so convincing in each of the roles i sometimes forget it is her playing all of them. Not sure where this show is going to go, but the ride is awesome thus far.Between the conspiracies of big pharma, the religious right and the culpability of law enforcement and the government(s) in the experiments it tacks a new tract every episode.

reviewText: show is never boring hoping that they continue with making season three great story line!watch on my Kindle evry night for a treat,
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Season Two has been good so far. The acting is just as good as season one, which is the element that really makes the shows great. (With the noted exception of the two cops. Both are bad actors that overplay their characters and remove you from the imersion of the story)They did try to expand the clone roster recently, adding a new clone who is transgendered and becoming a man. The concept is believable but it's just one step further than Tatiana Maslany can effectively pull off. It was a fun epsiode and seeing her with a beard was entertaining but the whole character was just a device to add some shock value and he didn't really advance the plot. He was more or less a side trip with a more elaborate thanneeded back stroy that appears to be a 1 episode run.That aside, season 2 has been great. It lacks some of the focus of season 1 but it all feels like it's a set up for big plans in season 3. Many many many shows do this and it's not a bad thing. But you spend season 2 watching the characters kind of stagnate while the plot develops around them. Sarah is running from Dyad. Cosima is trying to save herself from the genetic fault. Alison is in rehab. There are advancements in the background that appear to be setting up something big, but the character development has slowed down.On the plus side there also isn't any of the craziness with people growing tails and partying in night clubs for people with genetic modifcations. That was a season one element that just made the plot take a weird and uneeded left turn. They have managed to get the story line back to something that somewhat believable in season two (as believeable as you can make a show about a dozen genetic clones who all find each other)
summary: Better and worse than season 1 in various ways
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Season two is everty bit as good as season one. More questions answer but question come forth. Some people are not who they appear.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: I love love love this series. This season is just a good as the first one. BBC has done it again!
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Season 1 was excellent.  However season 2 was a major let-down.  There was little advancement in any of the major story lines left over from the first season; the whole second season feels like a lot of running around and wheel-spinning.  The writers didn't bother to take up any of the big ideas from the end of season 1, such as the ramifications of allowing corporations to patent engineered DNA.  A few new characters and story lines get introduced, but then nothing impactful is done with them.  Truly disappointing after the amazing first season.Tatiana Maslany's performance is still amazing; none of the problems are her fault.  The writers just didn't give her anything decent to work with.  All I can figure is that after all the critical acclaim for the first season, the writers just thought that anything they slapped together would work just fine.
summary: a let-down after an amazing first season
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Season two of Orphan Black is just as edgy and diverse as Season One. Tatiana plays all the clones masterfully. Editors do a great Job fusing and recombining.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Sorry but this is just a story of some Amish girl who dreams of playing with the Miami dolphins football team. Wow how riveting. Sorry but the wire is the best show ever and i would much rather watch too see Omar than some wannabes football player
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Omnipotent, omniscient, omnipresent evil is on the loose (what a totally boring concept), and only our heroine and her fellow clones stand in the breach, or, as enemies, are trying to break through the breach. An interesting premise, at least through the first half of season one, has now degenerated into Days of Our Lives. Tatiana Maslany gets full marks for playing about 50 different characters, but for this viewer the premise has worn thin, as it seems just about every series now on TV has used or is using a similar story line. If you're a fan of soaps, this is for you. If not, pass on.
summary: Promising Start, Now a Soap Opera
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: I find myself waiting weekly for the next new episode. Great show with a great cast that I tell all my friends to try out.

reviewText: The hook for this series gets set in the opening scene of the first episode and it's a roller coaster ride from that point forward. I bought the first season and will likely buy the second, and I very rarely buys shows. I'm a huge fan and I'm glad I found the series. Go BBC America!

reviewText: Still not quite at the end of the season, but between the first season and the twists and turns in the second, this has to be one of the best drama/scifi/action/thriller TV shows out there in recent history ... keeps you thinking ... Helena is still my favorite character ... crazy is as crazy does!

reviewText: Another great Syfy series.  The actress that plays the lead role and all of the other clones in the show is super talented.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: Orphan Black is compelling, suspenseful, funny, intriguing, alarming, charming and so much more than the sum of its parts.The writing is witty. The cinematography is brilliant. Each of the primary characters; Felix, Art, Shivon, Delphine  are all portrayed powerfully and extremely well.  The rest of the supporting cast; Lekey, Paul, Thomas, etc. are all pretty good.  But, Rachel, Helena, Cassima, Allison and especially Sarah are all played breathtakingly perfect,  in fact, absolutely perfect in every way. IMHO, Orphan Black is the best TV on TV right now.
summary: I believe this is the best series on tv.
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: It's quirky, funny and I find I am interested in even the most unattractive characters.  Maybe knowing they are clones gives me an empathy for them that I wouldn't normally have for such crazies.  It ain't their fault, you know/
summary: Don't know why but I love it!

reviewText: Seasons one and two are absolutely stunning in the writing, direction, production and superb performances. This series is absolutely a must-see for anyone into genetic engineering and all sciences dealing with nature/nurture, synthetic DNA and today's ethical dilemmas playing out exactly; Art imitating Life. Excellent actress!
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2

reviewText: I totally agree with everyone praising Tatiana's performances - she is awesome. Take a minute, tho, and give some credit to the people supporting her in the other roles. Felix, the two cops, Dr. Leekie, Donnie, Paul, and, especially, Mrs. S. Everyone one of these folks is perfectly cast. This is the best series on TV, period.

reviewText: There were boy clones, too.Duncan's book has to make its way to Delphine.Rachel seems irrelevant at this point.Helena gets kidnpped a lot.What happened to the trans-clone?We'll see if it is enough for a Season 3
Title: Orphan Black: Season 2
